title: How many Syrian Refugees will the UNHCR register in Turkey, Lebanon, Jordan, Iraq, Egypt and North Africa before 1 January 2017?
preds: As of today: 4,837,248 and only 4 days left.
Quite a jump from 4 to 8 December: + 26,000. No big jump afterwards (yet?)

4 December update is 4,810,710. Not even close to 5 million. Only 14 days left for this forecast to close, the number will not change by 190 000 in that short time frame.
http://data.unhcr.org/syrianrefugees/regional.php

4,810,710 as of 04 Dec, barely 3 thousand more than on 15 March 2016. Despite the fall of Aleppo, another 200,000 in less than a month in these winter months seems extremely unlikely (though this did happen last year, where the numbers jumped from 4,279,128 on 02 Dec 2015 to 4,595,198 on 31 Dec).
4,810,710. Not even close to 5 million as of 10 December, only 22 days left.
I have a rough count of a little over 4m 800.00 refugees; if Aleppo falls before the end of the year perhaps another 190,200 refugees will seek asylum in Turkey or other neighboring countries.
Doesn't look like anyone is keen to register more refugees before the end of the year. They may be there, but they're not registered.

Extrapolating from the trend, we would almost certainly (99%) get less than 5 million- however, the UNHCR tends to be late with its paperwork and manages to get a year-end rush of registrations in by Dec 31in order to make the numbers look as large/accurate as possible for the start of the next year.   You need only to to the graph of total registrations and look at the jumps that occurred between 15 Dec and 31 Dec in both 2014 and 2015.  http://data.unhcr.org/syrianrefugees/regional.php.   Hence, I am allowing some probability of a similar jump this December.   Unfortunately, this year is a little strange because over the last few months there have been reports of a trickle of refugees back into Syria- hence, it is theoretically possible that the year-end rush could result in a surprise large decline in the number of refugees rather than an increase- though I am not forecasting for this at the moment.

Turkey’s Erdogan threatens to let 3m refugees into Europe
https://www.ft.com/content/c5197e60-b2fc-11e6-9c37-5787335499a0

The UNHCR numbers for Syrian refugees has tapered off as of late and with the Raqqah offensive as the main focus of the military just kicking off and the population of Raqqah being less than 180k it would seem to be nessisary for the Russians or the Assad regime to cause a significant bump in refugees for it to exceed 5mil.

4,810,216 as of 07 November 2016. The total has remained between about 4775k and 4845k since mid February, and events in Syria don't suggest any reason for it to rise up to 5 million in the next six weeks.  Adjusting from 95/5/0
Difficulty in accurate counting the real numbers involved.

For some reason the UNHCR has some statistical anomalies around year-end.  In December of 2015, the number of registered refugees increased by nearly 300,000 during the month (about as many as in the prior six months combined.   In December of 2014, there wasn't a huge spike- instead it was reported on the first business day of January 2015, and was a jump of nearly 500,000 new registrations.   Must have been a busy New Year's Eve for UN accountants- haha. Clearly there is some sort of paperwork or bureaucratic quirk that results in these spikes.  Will the 2016 spike be recorded in December, or pushed until January.  And will it be a spike upward to reflect underreported arrivals, or will it be a decrease to reflect the departure of some refugees who have found homes abroad?

The continuing flow of Syrian refugees to neighbouring countries is being offset by the equal flow of refugees onward from these countries to Europe. This will continue to happen and with the strong action against ISIS in Syria and Iraq, its possible that refugees try to move back. A feature of continuous conflicts in other regions, such as Lebanon for example, is that refugees want to return home as soon as possible, and many times too soon. The level of refugees has been flat pretty much since the start of 2016 and has even decreased somewhat. Possible anti-immigration policies in Europe won't be implemented before 1 January 2017.

Only based on my > impression < of the graph at http://data.unhcr.org/syrianrefugees/regional.php and the assumption that there will be no major event until the end of this year that would lead to a rise. Even the impact of the intense fighting in Aleppo since the beginning of this year has been rather modest when it comes to the overall number of refugees. If ISIS is loosing ground in the north, i think it is more likely for people to return than to flee (no matter who "liberates" the territory/cities).
+5 on less than 5 million -- Passage of time

Updating univariate time series forecast obtained with 'forecast' function from R package of same name. It looks like UNHCR has modified their web page and is no longer posting downloadable data. So, I took the figure reported in the UNICEF Syria Crisis Situation Report as the total on October 16, used it as the October update to the monthly series I got from the last download (which ran through the end of September), and used that series to forecast. The new point estimate for end of 2016 is 4.82 million. Five million is just about the upper bound of the 75% confidence interval, so I get 87% for A, 12% for B, and round up to 1% for C.
Affirming last algorithmic forecast for now, which used end-of-September data, as the UNHCR figures still haven't been updated past Sept 30.
rate of registered refugees has held relatively steadily since last update - about 20-30K per month

Some 900 people have fled the Iraqi city of Mosul and crossed the border into Syria, the UN refugee agency says.
http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-37701235
The attack on Mossul will significantly increase the refugee numbers

Despite the tricky wording that leaves room for interpretation, if we take into account the time frame length and intensity of the past 2.5 years that brought us to the 4.8 mill figure only, it is not very likely the 5.6 mill will be exceeded.

Updating univariate monthly time series forecast with UNHCR data now reported through September 30. Almost unchanged. The point estimate for the end of 2016 is 4.84 million. Barring a sharp turn in the local trend, I expect the predicted probability of A to grow further as we add October data and thus shrink the number of steps ahead we're trying to anticipate.

Only way I see this hitting higher numbers is if Turkey or Lebannon decided to either register their refugees (very unlikely) or actively decided to try to move them on somewhere else eg Turkey falls out with EU and decides to try and force refugees into Europe.
round about 5 Million, yes, with a tendency to 6 Million Refugees.

in 2016 the rate of registered refugees is running around 25,000 a month.  The rate was far greater the first two years of the war.  The rate was approximately 75,000 a month in 2015.  There is approximately 4.8 million refugees registered end of September 2016.  The recent government offensive against Aleppo likely raises the rate of registered refugees for the remainder of the year.  Aleppo still has an estimated 1,000,000 civilians.

The civilians in Aleppo are trapped and I don't think there will be much of a refugee bump from Aleppians unless the Russians and Syrian Forces allow them to leave, which I doubt will happen. Meanwhile the US and everyone else is focused on Mosul, so Raqqah won't see much pressure nor will many other densely populated areas. For these reasons I expect the Syrian Refugee population to stay stable until the focus shifts away from Aleppo or the Rebels are able to break the siege.

The number are:
Total 4792,209 Turkey 57%
Lebanon 22%
Jordan 14%
Iraq 5%
Egypt 2% Like everybody else here I wonder if the number could rise because of Aleppo.

Thanks to @Anneinak ( https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/342099 ) http://data.unhcr.org/syrianrefugees/regional.php The numbers today are more or less the same as on 31 March 2016. It would appear that the number of refugees on UNHCR's books are in equilibrium between new arrivals and those being "de-registered" (perhaps finding permanent places to go, or even returning home). There could always be a sudden influx, especially from Aleppo, but it's beginning to look unlikely, with winter approaching.

4,793,209  as of today (reporting as of 9/30).  So, since it was  4,799,677 as of Sept 14th, there's been a decrease of 6,468! The highest number reported this year was back on May 16th  @ 4,844,111. From 1/1/16 to 5/16/16 there was an average of 1830 per day.  With 92 days  until the last count at the end of the year, if the rate increased to 1830 per day,  we'd see another 168,360 for a total of 4,961,569. I wonder if there will be a surge because of the battle in Aleppo, and when we might see it.

Numbers appear to have stabilised. 
Given that Turkey is not registering new refugees they are unlikely to change dramatically.

4,806,762
increased about 1k per day in the last week
if this rate remains constant,  the total will be about 4,900,000

Further strengthening Option 1, based on very stable registration. No signs that Turkey and/or Lebanon will review their current policies of not registering additional refugees. The possibility remains that we will see some form of data dump (although this is not expected by the UNHCR at this time as per prior answer to a request for comment), so I see the 15% for Option 2 as justified for the moment.
May be more upside risk than was previously forecast.

Most who could leave have left, however, the factions are escalating their offensive and with the US/Russia direct involvement, chances are high that another wave of refugees will do whatever it takes to leave Syria.
I don't see the number exploding and I believe many of those who are still there probably don't ever want to leave, or can't.

https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/324051 @T4B
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/319848 @ulfelder
Thanks to all the usual suspects who contributed to these comments as well.
Starting to think that it is likely to be low, if Turkey and Lebannon are not registering. Also by now perhaps most of the Syrians who would leave, have left? I feel, at present there is a lull in proceedings and without some major new outbreak, numbers will remain low. One issue that may lead to sudden increase in registrations would be if the non registereds in Turkey (or  Lebannon) suddenly decided to move to one of the other countries, where they would be registered.

Due to wars, poverty, poor governments and let us not forget religious differences, millions will migrate out of their homelands.   Unfortunately for many their dreams of a better life will not be realized.    Just too many to be absorbed effectively.

The number has not changed much since March. As others have pointed out, the number jumped by 500,000 between 29 December 2015 and 02 January 2016. Paperwork backlog, I assume. If the same thing happens this year, I hope it will not happen before the holiday weekend. If the number jumps on 2 January, it won't affect this question.
today the number is 4,800,087, up 410 in the last 5 days.  The number seems pretty static.
situation seems to be improving in Syria

Numbers have stabilised over the past several months around 4.8mm, so a number below 5mm looks probable.  My concern is that the UNHCR suffers from paperwork lags and in particular look at the data comparing the last week of December 2015 with the first week of January 2016.  If you believe their stats, 500,000 refugees arrived over Christian New Year's weekend! Obviously there was either a delay in processing paperwork that had been lying around (and a rush to get it in for the New year) or they reclassified a large number of people as refugees- haven't done any digging to determine what actually happened, but this increases the risk of an large, unexpected change in the refugee numbers around year-end.
pressure inside Syria seems to be abating, cease fire etc -> should mean less refugees

@T4B has done some amazing research, reaching out to UNHCR personnel.  See
http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/324051 With the ceasefire in Aleppo basically holding, there's hope that the actual refugee flow will decrease. Meanwhile, the number of refugees as recorded on the UNHCR website continues to decrease, and is now 4,799,677: down 8,344 in 8 days!

Updated forecast from univariate time series model using monthly data now available through August 31 from UNHCR. Point estimate for end of 2016 is 4.85 million; 5 million is just about the upper bound of the 50-percent CI; and 5.4 million is approximately the upper bound for the 95-percent CI.
Further adjustment because the ceasefire seems to hold for the moment, reducing the chance of a massive refugee influx due to developments of the conflict itself.

Hit Enter to early, here is my earlier comment: As mentioned before, I reached out to the UNHCR for details on the curious "data dumps" in the data. Here are my questions and the corresponding answers. tl;dr: the data dumps were due to the Turkish government providing data at the end of the year and Turkey has halted all registration for the time being and no data dumps are expected for 2016. The UNHCR has no public forecasts of its own currently. As a consequence I will swing hard to Option 1 1) what was the nature of this adjustment, e.g. why did it happen? 
Some countries (particularly Turkey) disclosed registered data at certain point of time rather than in regular basis which led to such spike at certain point of the time. Please note that the registration in Turkey is done by the Government and we only get data when they release hence you may notice such spike but movement from Syria may not be in line with the spike. 2) Why weren't there similar adjustments in 2012 and 2013? 
As explained.. it is based on when countries provided data for public consumption. 3) Will we see such an adjustment at the end of 2016? If yes, what is its expected size? 
There are no waiting registration of Syrian refugee at this stage in the neighboring countries hence it is not expected such spike unless there is mass movement from Syria to neighboring countries in future. 4) In your 2016/2017 Strategic Overview you forecast about 4.6 million registered Syrian refugees by 31 December 2016. This number has already been surpassed. What is your current forecast for the total number of registered refugees on 31 December 2016 and how do you get to this number? 
Yes you are right, we crossed the planning figure for the registered Syrian in the region and we have different projections scenarios but unfortunately not agreed yet hence are not available for public. New projection will be available somewhere in late November or December this year. cc/ @Anneinak @ulfelder @Raahul_kumar

As mentioned before, I reached out to the UNHCR for details on the curious "data dumps" in the data. Here are my questions and the corresponding answers. tl;dr: the data dumps were due to the Turkish government providing data at the end of the year and Turkey has halted all registration for the time being and no data dumps are expected for 2016. The UNHCR has no public forecasts of its own currently. As a consequence I will swing hard to Option 1  1) what was the nature of this adjustment, e.g. why did it happen?
Some countries (particularly Turkey) disclosed registered data at certain point of time rather than in regular basis which led to such spike at certain point of the time. Please note that the registration in Turkey is done by the Government and we only get data when they release hence you may notice such spike but movement from Syria may not be in line with the spike. 2) Why weren't there similar adjustments in 2012 and 2013?
As explained.. it is based on when countries provided data for public consumption. 3) Will we see such an adjustment at the end of 2016? If yes, what is its expected size?
There are no waiting registration of Syrian refugee at this stage in the neighboring countries hence it is not expected such spike unless there is mass movement from Syria to neighboring countries in future. 4) In your 2016/2017 Strategic Overview you forecast about 4.6 million registered Syrian refugees by 31 December 2016. This number has already been surpassed. What is your current forecast for the total number of registered refugees on 31 December 2016 and how do you get to this number?
Yes you are right, we crossed the planning figure for the registered Syrian in the region and we have different projections scenarios but unfortunately not agreed yet hence are not available for public. New projection will be available somewhere in late November or December this year. cc/ @Anneinak @ulfelder @Raahul_kumar

I have a feeling we'll get another "data dump" this time and be safely over 5 million -- but I'm taking the crowd's pessimism into account for 5.4. Leaving a little probability aside to account for the chance that we really are seeing things slow to a crawl, but the boosts over the last two years were gigantic.
There is no light at the end of this tunnel. We are not doing anything that helps stop the insanity. Neither rationale thinking nor military action is in sight of prevailing.

Another scoring issue: for specific numbers "before 1 Jan. 2017".  It's possible all three could occur by 1/1/17.  So how is the question to be scored if multiple answers are correct?
---- Suspect the Q should read "on 1/1/17", or some similar wording. As of now, the less than "5 million" has already happened.  Should the question close? Can we select multiple options to be true "before the close date"?
No matter which number one chooses, it is a huge number of people.

Reverting to my original forecast, which used the univariate time series model selected by the forecast function in the R package of the same name, in response to @T4B's research on drivers of the apparent seasonality in previous years. This forecast comes from an exponential smoothing model that doesn't parameterize a seasonal jump at the end of each year.

The UNHCRs estimates are low, those countries reported totals are higher than 5M
As Turkey and others Take syria apart more refugess will follow.

There are approximately 1.3-1.5 million unregistered Syrian refugees.  4,812,993 refugees (registered, March 2016)[1]
6,130,000-6,320,000 refugees (based on UN estimate, March 2016)[2]
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Refugees_of_the_Syrian_Civil_War However T4B finds: "I've just found some interesting bits of information that have let me to reassess my forecast. The two most important hosts for Syrian refugees are Turkey and Lebanon. But it seems like both have decided to halt registration of refugees until further notice. In Lebanon this is official policy since 6 May 2015 (http://data.unhcr.org/syrianrefugees/country.php?id=122), while in Turkey this seems to be unofficial but with the same effect since about March 2016 (http://data.unhcr.org/syrianrefugees/country.php?id=224). Registered refugee counts in both countries are slowly decreasing since then. Turkey also seems to have closed the border with some reports of Turkish military shooting on Syrians to keep them from crossing it. The two countries also host the largest share of the unregistered refugee population, making it unlikely that this population will enter the statistic as long as the mentioned policy remains in effect. Neither Turkey, nor Lebanon have indicated in any way that they will restart registering refugees any time soon and the domestic political climate in both countries isn't conductive to do so."
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/319547

The rate of increase in 2016 has been much slower than previous years, especially in recent months. If this continues for the rest of the year it won't break 5 million.  A 0.6 million increase in 4 months happened previously but not since 2014.  A significant change in the situation could bump figures up again but probably not to >5.4 million.

There are not so many Syrians left and Turkish incursion could create safe zones within Syria.
However turkish incursion might also create new streams of refugees. 
The worst stream (not in quantity, but in undesirability) might still be the one of the IS loyalists fleeing when they'll finally lose.

reconsidering:  with a huge backlog of unregistered refugees, if there was a decision to finally register them, 5.4m could be exceeded.  To save myself from Brier disaster, I'm going to change 0 to 2%.

see T4B  http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/319547 I'm assuming that Turkey & Lebanon won't start registering refugees, so that there won't be a huge spike in registered refugees in the last quarter of this year, as was seen in the past 2 years.

The refugee count seems to have peaked in early-May at 4.837m and has fallen to 4.808m since then.
If the current baseline is stable; even though the military situation in Aleppo, over the past summer, has not been good. 
 Perhaps the prevetative measures by the EU against further flows through Turkey is one of, if not the  main cause of the static refugee count.  
Arguments in favor of an increase in refugees:
---Any increase will show up in the numbers, and it is close to 5m.
---Syrian / Iranian, advance on Aleppo could destabilize the area, but, conditions have not been good there anyway.
---Turkey could re-open routes to the EU, motivating more Syrians to leave.
Reasons the refugee count will fall:
---Stable at 4,8m since May
---US / Russian cease fire negotiations continue
---Turkey is reported (FT, today) to want to establish a safe zone in newly acquired Syrian areas along the Turkish border.  The goals is reported to be to settle Syrian refugees and rebels there (and likely to prevent the Syrian Kurds from obtaining areas on the Turkish border).
---The combination of Assad, Russia, Iran, Turkey may minimize any further anti-Assad rebel / Kurd gains in the short term.

I've just found some interesting bits of information that have let me to reassess my forecast. The two most important hosts for Syrian refugees are Turkey and Lebanon. But it seems like both have decided to halt registration of refugees until further notice. In Lebanon this is official policy since 6 May 2015 (http://data.unhcr.org/syrianrefugees/country.php?id=122), while in Turkey this seems to be unofficial but with the same effect since about March 2016 (http://data.unhcr.org/syrianrefugees/country.php?id=224). Registered refugee counts in both countries are slowly decreasing since then. Turkey also seems to have closed the border with some reports of Turkish military shooting on Syrians to keep them from crossing it. The two countries also host the largest share of the unregistered refugee population, making it unlikely that this population will enter the statistic as long as the mentioned policy remains in effect. Neither Turkey, nor Lebanon have indicated in any way that they will restart registering refugees any time soon and the domestic political climate in both countries isn't conductive to do so. The two "jumps" on 31 December of 2014 and 2015 that I have described in an earlier forecast can be traced to the Turkish parts of the data. I'm not sure what the current Turkish policy means for the chances of these events repeating themselves, but I have lodged a corresponding request for clarification with the UNHCR. I will continue to assume that there is a chance of such an anomaly occurring for the time being. Overall I will adjust my forecast to 40/55/5 on the basis of this new information. If a data dump at the end of the year becomes unrealistic, I will change further to option 1.

based on analysis by
@T4B http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/319091
@ulfelder http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/319325 I've made an arbitrary adjustment.  Because recent months have shown a decrease, I:
reduced +5.4m  by 4%
increased -5.0m by 2%
increased 5-5.4 by 2% I have no idea how to adjust for possible future political or military events.
Nor do I know how to factor in the very recent changes in Turkey & with the Kurds.

After I made my initial forecast using a model that did not account for seasonality (see below), I noticed @T4B's comment pointing out the seasonality in the data and confirmed that point statistically. So, I switched to an ARIMA model that accounts for seasonality and got to the forecasts now shown.

These forecasts come from an algorithmically-selected time series model estimated with monthly summaries of the weekly data downloaded from the UNHCR site through mid-August 2016 (last obs dated August 16). The point estimate for the end of the year from this model using those data is 4.92 million. NB. As you can see in the chart on the UNHCR site if you look closely, the count actually *declined* in the first two weeks of August. So beware the assumption of upward progression.
My analysis followed the same logic as @Raahul_Kumar, with the same conclusion.  It makes me nervous when a GJ question seems straight-forward.

Currently the total is at 4,808,021. So what we are asking here is how probable is it that the number of registered refugees increases by about 200,000/between 200,000 and 600,000/more than 600,000? Even more specifically, how probable is it that we see these kind of increases within the last four months of the calendar year? On a purely statistical level, this is easy to answer: Year | Increase over the last four month
2012 | 298,494
2013 | 466,960
2014 | 752,002
2015 | 507,120 Every single year saw an increase of over 200,000, while only one year saw an increase of over 600,000. This would result in a 0%/75%/25% answer to the question and I take this as my starting assumption. Seasonality and bureaucracy is important in this data series. Note the huge jumps in December of 2014 and 2015. This is clearly not related to actual refugee flows across borders, but to some form of data dump, likely to reconcile the common database at year's end. In this context it is important to note that at the end of 2015, there were about 2 million unregistered Syrian refugees present in the area, so increased registration doesn't necessarily has to correlate with increased flows across borders (http://data.unhcr.org/syrianrefugees/download.php?id=9937). But the data also reveals that the number of registered refugees across the region has shrunk for three months in a row including August 2016, the first time it has done so. And the increase in the first 8 months of this year has been by far the lowest compared to 2015, 2014 and 2013. On top of that the number of refugees forecasted by the UNHCR to be present at the end of 2016 was only 4.6 million, which has already been surpassed. I will therefore adapt my forecast to 20%/75%/5% based on my assumption that a jump of >600,000 is highly unlikely, while a stagnation is a reasonable assumption given recent data and developments (there are also clear indications that Turkey and other countries are trying to limit the number of refugees entering their country and official systems). But given patterns from recent years, a last minute, likely administrative, jump in numbers remains the overwhelming possibility. If current data trends continue I expect a 33%/62%/1% split at the end of the year.

4.5 million Syrian refugees at start of 2016. 4.8 million today. 212651 refugees total since the start of this year. Approximately 30378 refugees per month. 4 months left in year = 4921514.857142857 or approximately 4.9 million refugees for this year. There is a maximum upper limit to refugees, Syria's population isn't that large. "Population of Syria 2015 As of 1 January 2016, the population of Syria was estimated to be 18 215 868 people. This is a decrease of -2.26 % (-421 579 people) compared to population of 18 637 447 the year before. "
http://countrymeters.info/en/Syria

Another 4 - 5% would bring the total to more than 5 million.  But it would take more than a 10% increase to pass the 5.4 million mark.  I believe the exodus will continue but short of complete chaos it is hard to image an increase of more than 10%.

I understand that the end date for this Q is 01 January, and we are relying on UNHCR for numbers, currently 4.8M.  What I don’t know is when the count starts or even what it is counting.  Is this 4.8M registered refugees since the UNHCR was set up in 1950, or the beginning of the current unpleasantness, or the beginning of this year, or yesterday afternoon, or only those currently being attended to by UNHCR?  And what exactly is a “registered refugee”?  Are refugees ever deregistered?   I can’t find these things out anywhere on the UNHCR site, but I am olde and feeble of mind so the information may be there—anybody got anything on this?  It may not matter, of course, if the intent of the question is to guess out what the number on that graph will be as of 01 January.  However, I can’t help feeling I could guess out that number more precisely if I knew what it meant.   I also can’t help feeling that this Q, like so many others, was posted in haste (post-haste?) without taking the time to understand what it meant.  Feelings are tricky things.
